title: Warm-up Session
text:
Time: 09:30-10:00
Facilitator: Lars Schöbitz

title: Warm-up Session
text:
Session Overview
Start the conference with an engaging warm-up session designed to:

Break the ice and help participants get to know each other
Create a welcoming and collaborative atmosphere
Set the tone for productive discussions throughout the conference
Build connections within the openwashdata community

title: Warm-up Session
text:
Format
This interactive session will include:

Positive Feedback Exercise
A structured activity where participants:

Pair up with someone they haven’t met before
Share brief introductions and backgrounds
Exchange positive observations or appreciations
Introduce their partner to a small group



Community Connections
Quick networking rounds to:

Discover shared interests and expertise
Identify potential collaboration opportunities
Build the foundation for hackathon teams (Day 2)

title: Warm-up Session
text:
What to Expect

Active participation and movement
Informal, friendly atmosphere
Opportunities to meet diverse community members
Energy and enthusiasm to kick off the conference

title: Warm-up Session
text:
Tips for Participation

Come with an open mind
Be ready to step out of your comfort zone
Bring business cards or contact information to share
Think about what you hope to achieve at the conference

title: Day 1: Community & Governance
text:
Laptop: Required for shared note-taking, especially in the afternoon sessions.
Google Doc access: We will take notes in a shared Google Doc. You will receive an email to test if you can access it. If you did not receive an email, please contact the organizers.
Ideas for Hackathon: Think about potential projects or topics you or somene else could work on during the hackathon on Day 2.

title: Day 1: Community & Governance
text:
Session Details

Morning Sessions
The day begins with a warm-up session led by Lars, followed by a reflection on the openwashdata community’s journey and future direction. Emmanuel will share insights on data stewardship implementation at BASEflow Malawi.


Afternoon Sessions
After lunch, Liz will present on the intersection of openwashdata and Open Research Data from the Global Health Engineering perspective.
The afternoon continues with: - Positive Gossip Exercise - An energizing warm-up activity to reconnect after lunch - Governance Discussion - Reflection on different governance style and how we might shape the future structure and decision-making processes of openwashdata - Hackathon Ideation - Preparing a long list of ideas for the hackathon on Day 2 - Lean Coffee - An open, democratically-driven discussion on topics that matter most to the community

title: Day 1: Community & Governance
text:
What to Bring

Laptop for afternoon sessions
Note-taking materials
Ideas for projects for the hackathon
Questions about openwashdata’s future direction

title: Governance
text:
A 10X engineer is one who can bring together ten other engineers and emerge with a shared understanding and rough consensus of the problem being solved and work that needs to be done.
— Lorin Hochstein


In this house we call them “project managers”.
— Greg Wilson






Software is created and run to answer a question
Papers, theses, and other reports are the product
The software is “just” a tool
Shades into projects that produce software for other researchers to use






Degree(s) in some research domain
Little or no formal training in software development
In a team of 1–12 people
Timelines of weeks to months




XKCD Dependency cartoon







Don’t remember much statistics…
…but I’ve built a lot of complicated software…
…and I’ve been lucky enough to hang out with some very smart people



  









Then


Now


Next




Dropbox


Git repository


Branching workflow




“Just do it”


Slack / mailing list


Martha’s Rules




Interactive analysis


A big pile of scripts


Build tools / CI




Word / Google Docs


Notebooks / LaTeX


Site builder




“It doesn’t crash”


“Are there any NAs?”


Assertions / unit tests




“Um, hi?”


README + LICENSE


CONTRIBUTING + CoC








Original workshop: Daniel Standage and Greg Wilson
Producing Open Source Software: Karl Fogel
Research Software Engineering with Python: Damien Irving, Kate Hertweck, Luke Johnston, Joel Ostblom, Charlotte Wickham, and Greg Wilson
And everyone cited in the bibliography




Cover of ‘Research Software Engineering with Python’







Who uses your software?
How do they find it?
Who decides what will happen next?
How is that communicated?
Who can make what kinds of changes?
What happens automatically?
How are newcomers brought on board?

title: Governance
text:
Time: 14:00-15:00
Format: Interactive discussion with presentations
Today we’ll explore governance models for open research software communities, drawing from best practices and adapting them to openwashdata’s needs.


“A 10X engineer is one who can bring together ten other engineers and emerge with a shared understanding”

title: Governance Discussion
text:
Key Topics

Community Structure

Current governance model review
Roles and responsibilities within the community
Decision-making processes
Communication channels and transparency



Sustainability Planning

Long-term vision for openwashdata
Resource allocation and funding models
Community growth strategies
Partnership development



Standards and Guidelines

Data quality standards
Contribution guidelines
Code of conduct
Licensing and data sharing policies

title: Governance Discussion
text:
Expected Outcomes

Governance Framework: Draft outline of governance structure
Action Items: Concrete steps for implementation
Working Groups: Formation of specialized teams
Timeline: Roadmap for governance improvements

title: Governance Discussion
text:
How to Prepare

Review current openwashdata documentation
Think about governance models from other open communities
Consider what aspects of governance are most important to you
Prepare questions or suggestions

title: Governance Discussion
text:
Format
The session will include:

Brief presentation of current state
Small group discussions
Plenary sharing and synthesis
Action planning







Work in Progress



This session is currently being developed. More details will be added as they become available.

title: openwashdata Conference 2025
text:
This is an initial prompt to get you started. Layout a Quarto website for the 2025 openwashdata conference. Use the following website as a template: https://gitforsci-cis.github.io/website/
You can find the content of the three days here: https://openwashdata.org/pages/events/2025-openwashdata-conference/
For the website layout (https://github.com/gitforsci-cis/website/blob/main/_quarto.yml) create sections:

pre-requisites for Day 2

make the below in one file with more details and links, help MacOS users and Windows users

Preparation for hackathon
Get Claude Code Max plan
Verify that you can open terminal app
Install python
Verify that you can log into GitHub account
Create a folder on your machine that stores files local (not OneDrive, Google Drive, etc.)

Name the folder: gitrepos

Accept the invitation to join GitHub organisation: openwashdata-conf


day 1

make it one subpage (href) per session / module. The WIP sessions are:

Warm-up

Positive feedback

Governance
Ideation for hackathon
[[Lean Coffee]]


day 2

make sub-pages along the agenda

day 3

make the whole day one subpage


Make a detailed plan before you proceed building the website and ultrathink.

title: Setup Check
text:
Time: 10:00-10:30
Format: Hands-on verification

title: Setup Check
text:
Session Overview
Before we start coding, let’s ensure everyone has their development environment properly configured. This session will help identify and resolve any setup issues.

title: Setup Check
text:
Checklist Verification
We’ll verify each prerequisite step by step:

1. Claude Code Access
# In your terminal, verify Claude Code is accessible
# Try a simple command with Claude Code

Confirm Max plan is active
Test basic functionality
Troubleshoot any access issues



2. Terminal/Command Line
# Test basic commands
echo "Hello, openwashdata!"
pwd
ls -la


3. Python Environment
# Check Python installation
python3 --version
pip3 --version

# Test Python functionality
python3 -c "print('Python is working!')"


4. Git Configuration
# Check Git installation
git --version

# Verify Git configuration
git config --global user.name
git config --global user.email
If not configured:
git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your.email@example.com"


5. GitHub Access
# Test GitHub SSH connection (if using SSH)
ssh -T git@github.com

# Or test with HTTPS
git ls-remote https://github.com/openwashdata-conf/test-repo.git


6. Working Directory
# Navigate to your gitrepos folder
cd ~/gitrepos  # macOS/Linux
# or
cd C:\gitrepos  # Windows

# Create a test repository
mkdir test-setup
cd test-setup
git init


7. Organization Access
Verify you can access the openwashdata-conf organization:

Visit github.com/openwashdata-conf
Confirm you see member access
Check for any pending invitations

title: Setup Check
text:
Common Issues and Solutions

Claude Code Not Working

Verify subscription status
Check internet connection
Try logging out and back in
Contact support if needed



Python Command Not Found

macOS/LinuxWindows


# Try python3 instead of python
python3 --version

# Add to PATH if needed
echo 'export PATH="/usr/local/bin:$PATH"' >> ~/.zshrc
source ~/.zshrc


# Verify Python is in PATH
where python

# If not found, add to PATH through System Properties
# Or reinstall Python with "Add to PATH" checked





Git Push/Pull Issues

Check authentication (SSH vs HTTPS)
Verify repository permissions
Ensure correct remote URL
Update credentials if needed

title: Setup Check
text:
Team Formation Check
While we verify setups:

Confirm your team members
Exchange contact information
Decide on communication channel
Choose a team name
Designate a GitHub repo owner

title: Setup Check
text:
Ready to Hack!
Once all checks pass:

✅ Development environment ready
✅ Team formed and connected
✅ Project idea selected
✅ GitHub repository planned
✅ Communication channel established

title: Setup Check
text:
Need Help?
If you encounter issues:

Raise your hand - Mentors will assist
Check with teammates - They might have solutions
Use Slack channel - Post specific error messages
Pair programming - Work together on one machine







Don’t Skip This!



A properly configured environment is crucial for a productive hackathon. Take the time now to resolve any issues.

title: Ideation Finalization
text:
Time: 10:45-11:15
Format: Team planning session

title: Ideation Finalization
text:
Session Overview
Transform yesterday’s ideas into concrete hackathon projects. This session helps teams finalize their project scopes and create actionable development plans.

title: Ideation Finalization
text:
Project Planning Framework

1. Define the Problem (5 minutes)
Answer these questions:

What specific problem are we solving?
Who will benefit from our solution?
What’s the current pain point?
How will we measure success?

Example: > “Field workers struggle to validate water quality data in real-time, leading to errors that are discovered weeks later during analysis.”


2. Scope the Solution (10 minutes)
Minimum Viable Product (MVP):

Core functionality only
What can we demo by 15:30?
What would make this “working”?
What can we skip for now?

Nice-to-have features:

List for future development
Prioritize by impact
Document for showcase



3. Technical Planning (10 minutes)
Architecture decisions:

Programming language(s)
Key libraries/frameworks
Data sources needed
Output format

Task breakdown:

Setup and configuration
Core functionality
User interface (if applicable)
Testing and validation
Documentation



4. Team Roles (5 minutes)
Assign responsibilities:

Lead Developer: Core logic implementation
UI/UX Developer: Interface and user experience
Data Wrangler: Sample data and testing
Documentation: README and demo prep
Project Manager: Timeline and coordination

Note: Roles can overlap in small teams

title: Ideation Finalization
text:
Project Templates

Data Processing Tool
**Problem:** [Specific data challenge]
**Solution:** Script/tool that [processes/validates/transforms] data
**Input:** [Data format/source]
**Output:** [Cleaned/processed data format]
**Tech Stack:** Python/R + relevant libraries


Visualization Dashboard
**Problem:** [What insights are hidden?]
**Solution:** Interactive dashboard showing [metrics/trends]
**Data Source:** [openwashdata API/CSV files]
**Features:** [Charts/filters/exports]
**Tech Stack:** JavaScript/Python + visualization library


API/Integration
**Problem:** [Integration/access challenge]
**Solution:** API that [connects/serves/processes]
**Endpoints:** [List key endpoints]
**Authentication:** [Method if needed]
**Tech Stack:** FastAPI/Express + database

title: Ideation Finalization
text:
GitHub Repository Setup
Create your team repository:
# Navigate to your gitrepos folder
cd ~/gitrepos

# Create and enter project directory
mkdir openwashdata-[project-name]
cd openwashdata-[project-name]

# Initialize Git repository
git init

# Create initial README
echo "# [Project Name]" > README.md
echo "" >> README.md
echo "## Problem Statement" >> README.md
echo "[Your problem description]" >> README.md
echo "" >> README.md
echo "## Solution" >> README.md
echo "[Your solution approach]" >> README.md
echo "" >> README.md
echo "## Team" >> README.md
echo "- Member 1: Role" >> README.md
echo "- Member 2: Role" >> README.md

# Initial commit
git add README.md
git commit -m "Initial commit: Project setup"

title: Ideation Finalization
text:
Success Criteria
By the end of this session, each team should have:

✅ Clear problem statement
✅ Defined MVP scope
✅ Technical approach decided
✅ Tasks assigned to team members
✅ GitHub repository created
✅ README with project overview

title: Ideation Finalization
text:
Tips for Success

Start small: Better to have a working simple solution than an incomplete complex one
Use existing data: Don’t spend time creating test data - use openwashdata resources
Leverage Claude Code: Use AI assistance for boilerplate and complex algorithms
Communicate constantly: Regular check-ins prevent duplicate work
Document as you go: Update README throughout the day

title: Ideation Finalization
text:
Ready to Start Hacking?
Once planning is complete:

Share your repository link in Slack
Post your problem statement
Start with setup and configuration
Begin implementing core features
Check in with mentors early and often







Remember



The goal is learning and collaboration, not perfection. Have fun and experiment!

title: Work Sessions
text:
Work Session Guidelines

Effective Collaboration
Communication: - Regular team check-ins (every 30 min) - Share progress and blockers - Ask for help early - Update shared documents
Version Control:
# Commit frequently
git add .
git commit -m "Add: [feature description]"

# Push to remote repository
git push origin main

# Pull teammate changes
git pull origin main


Using Claude Code Effectively
Good prompts for Claude Code:

Specific Implementation: > “Create a Python function that validates water quality data against WHO standards. The function should check pH (6.5-8.5), turbidity (<5 NTU), and return validation errors.”
Debugging Help: > “This function throws a KeyError when processing CSV files. Here’s the code and error message. How can I fix it?”
Code Improvement: > “Refactor this data processing code to be more efficient and add error handling for missing values.”
Documentation: > “Generate comprehensive docstrings for these functions and create a usage example for the README.”



Development Workflow

Session 1: Foundation (11:15-12:30)
Goals: - Environment setup complete - Core data structures defined - Basic functionality working - Initial tests passing
Checklist: - [ ] Dependencies installed - [ ] Project structure created - [ ] Core modules outlined - [ ] Sample data loaded - [ ] First function working


Session 2: Features (13:30-15:00)
Goals: - Main features implemented - User interface functional - Data flow complete - Error handling added
Checklist: - [ ] Key features working - [ ] Input/output verified - [ ] Basic UI complete - [ ] Edge cases handled - [ ] Integration tested


Session 3: Polish (15:00-15:30)
Goals: - Documentation complete - Demo prepared - Code cleaned up - Repository organized
Checklist: - [ ] README updated - [ ] Usage examples added - [ ] Code commented - [ ] Demo script ready - [ ] Presentation planned

title: Work Sessions
text:
Available Resources

Mentors
Technical mentors are circulating to help with: - Architecture decisions - Debugging assistance - Code reviews - Best practices - Tool recommendations


Data Sources
openwashdata resources: - API Documentation - Sample Datasets - Data Schemas


Quick References
Python Data Processing:
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

# Load data
df = pd.read_csv('water_quality.csv')

# Basic processing
df_clean = df.dropna()
df_filtered = df[df['ph'] > 6.5]
JavaScript Visualization:
// Using Chart.js
const ctx = document.getElementById('myChart');
const chart = new Chart(ctx, {
    type: 'line',
    data: waterQualityData,
    options: chartOptions
});
Git Commands:
# Check status
git status

# Create branch
git checkout -b feature-name

# Merge changes
git checkout main
git merge feature-name

title: Work Sessions
text:
Common Challenges

Time Management

Set mini-deadlines
Focus on MVP first
Don’t over-engineer
Leave time for documentation



Technical Issues

Import errors: Check package installation
API limits: Use cached/sample data
Merge conflicts: Communicate before major changes
Performance: Optimize later, functionality first



Team Dynamics

Assign clear ownership
Respect different skill levels
Share knowledge actively
Celebrate small wins

title: Work Sessions
text:
Progress Tracking
Use this template in your repository:
## Progress Log

### Session 1 (11:15-12:30)
- [x] Task 1 completed
- [x] Task 2 completed
- [ ] Task 3 in progress

### Session 2 (13:30-15:00)
- [ ] Feature A
- [ ] Feature B

### Session 3 (15:00-15:30)
- [ ] Documentation
- [ ] Demo preparation

title: Work Sessions
text:
Final Push Checklist
Before the showcase:

Code: Main functionality working?
Docs: README explains project?
Demo: Can you show it working?
Team: Everyone knows their part?
Time: Presentation under 5 minutes?







Remember



Done is better than perfect! Focus on demonstrating your core idea.

title: Day 3: Social Day
text: After two intensive days of learning and creating, join us for a relaxing social day to strengthen community bonds and enjoy the beautiful Swiss countryside.

text: After two intensive days of learning and creating, join us for a relaxing social day to strengthen community bonds and enjoy the beautiful Swiss countryside.

title: Day 3: Social Day
text:
Activity Details

Morning: Lama Farm Yacana
10:30-11:45 - Guided Tour
Experience a unique Swiss lama farm! During our visit:

Meet friendly lamas and alpacas
Learn about sustainable farming practices
Enjoy the peaceful countryside setting
Photo opportunities with the animals
Discover connections between agriculture and water management

What to know: - Wear comfortable walking shoes - Bring a camera - Family-friendly activity - English-speaking guide


Midday: Juckerfarm
13:00-14:30 - Farm Lunch
Juckerfarm is a popular Swiss destination offering:

Farm-to-table dining experience
Local seasonal produce
Vegetarian and dietary options available
Beautiful outdoor seating
Farm shop with local products

Lunch included: - Main course - Non-alcoholic beverages - Dessert
Please inform us of dietary restrictions by July 10


Afternoon: Badi Seegräben
14:30-15:45 - Lake Swimming
Relax at a traditional Swiss “Badi” (public swimming area):

Natural lake swimming
Sunbathing areas
Changing facilities available
Snack bar on site
Optional: lawn games and activities

What to bring: - Swimsuit and towel - Sunscreen - Change of clothes - Water shoes (optional)

title: Day 3: Social Day
text:
Transportation

Train Details
Outbound: - Meet: 09:15 at Zurich HB (Main Station) - Departure: 09:30 - Train: S14 direction Hinwil - Duration: ~30 minutes
Return: - Multiple return options available - Group return planned for 15:45 - Individual return possible
Tickets: - Covered by conference - Valid for zones 110, 111, 154 - Keep ticket for return journey


Walking Routes
Lama Farm to Juckerfarm: - Distance: 2.5 km - Duration: 30-40 minutes - Terrain: Easy, mostly flat - Scenic countryside views

title: Project Showcase
text:
Time: 15:30-16:15
Format: Team presentations

title: Project Showcase
text:
Showcase Overview
The culmination of our hackathon! Each team presents their project to the community, demonstrating solutions built to address openwashdata challenges.

title: Project Showcase
text:
Presentation Format

Time Allocation
5 minutes per team: - 3 minutes: Demo and explanation - 1 minute: Technical approach - 1 minute: Q&A and feedback


Presentation Structure

Problem Statement (30 seconds)

What challenge did you address?
Why is it important?

Solution Demo (2 minutes)

Live demonstration preferred
Show key functionality
Highlight user benefits

Technical Approach (1 minute)

Technologies used
Architecture overview
Key challenges overcome

Next Steps (30 seconds)

Future development plans
How others can contribute
Repository and documentation

Q&A (1 minute)

Answer audience questions
Receive feedback
Note suggestions

title: Project Showcase
text:
Presentation Tips

Do’s

Start with impact: Show what your solution does immediately
Keep it simple: Focus on core functionality
Be honest: Share what works and what’s still in progress
Show enthusiasm: Your passion is contagious
Credit team: Acknowledge all contributors



Don’ts

Don’t apologize for incomplete features
Don’t spend time on setup/installation
Don’t read from slides
Don’t exceed time limit
Don’t forget to breathe!

title: Project Showcase
text:
Demo Best Practices

Preparation

Test everything: Run through demo multiple times
Have backup: Screenshots/video if live demo fails
Prepare data: Use realistic sample data
Check equipment: Test projector/screen connection
Assign roles: Who presents what?



During Demo
## Demo Checklist
- [ ] Start with working state
- [ ] Explain what you're showing
- [ ] Go slowly - audience needs time
- [ ] Highlight key features
- [ ] Show actual output/results


Technical Setup

Close unnecessary applications
Increase font size for visibility
Have terminal/browser ready
Disable notifications
Use presentation mode if available

title: Project Showcase
text:
Evaluation Criteria
While this isn’t a competition, we celebrate:

Innovation: Creative approach to problems
Impact: Potential benefit to community
Technical Merit: Code quality and architecture
Collaboration: Teamwork and knowledge sharing
Documentation: Clear explanation and future usability

title: Project Showcase
text:
Showcase Participation

As a Presenter

Be proud of your work
Welcome feedback gracefully
Network with interested parties
Share repository links
Follow up on suggestions



As an Audience Member

Give full attention to presenters
Ask constructive questions
Offer positive feedback
Note projects to explore later
Connect with interesting teams

title: Project Showcase
text:
Post-Showcase

Immediate Actions

Share Resources:

Post repository links in Slack
Share presentation materials
Document feedback received

Connect:

Exchange contacts with interested parties
Discuss collaboration opportunities
Plan follow-up meetings

Celebrate:

Acknowledge team effort
Reflect on learning
Enjoy the achievement




Follow-up Actions
Within 1 week: - Update repository with showcase feedback - Create issues for suggested improvements - Write blog post about experience - Thank mentors and organizers
Ongoing: - Continue development if motivated - Contribute to other teams’ projects - Share at local meetups - Integrate into openwashdata ecosystem

title: Project Showcase
text:
Recognition
All participants receive:

Certificate of participation
Project featured on openwashdata blog
Repository in community showcase
Invitation to present at future events

title: Project Showcase
text:
Example Presentation Script

“Hi, we’re Team [Name], and we built [Project] to solve [Problem].
Here’s how it works: [Demo key feature]
We used [Technologies] because [Reasoning].
The biggest challenge was [Challenge] which we solved by [Solution].
Next, we plan to [Future plans].
You can find our code at [Repository URL]. We welcome contributions!
Questions?”







Remember



Every project is valuable! Whether it’s a simple script or complex application, you’ve contributed to the openwashdata mission.

title: Day 2: Claude Code Hackathon
text:
Hackathon Overview
Day 2 is dedicated to hands-on development using Claude Code to create tools and solutions for the openwashdata ecosystem.

What We’ll Build

Data processing pipelines
Visualization tools
APIs and integrations
Documentation systems
Quality assurance tools



Support Available

Technical mentors circulating
Claude Code assistance
openwashdata team guidance
Peer collaboration

title: Day 2: Claude Code Hackathon
text:
What to Bring

Laptop with prerequisites installed
Power adapter
GitHub account credentials
Project ideas from Day 1
Enthusiasm!

title: Day 2: Claude Code Hackathon
text:
Hackathon Rules

Collaboration: Work in teams of 3-5 people
Open Source: All code must be openly licensed
Time Box: Stop coding at 15:00 sharp
Showcase: Each team presents for 5 minutes
Have Fun: This is about learning and community

title: Day 2: Claude Code Hackathon
text:
Resources

openwashdata Documentation
Claude Code Documentation
GitHub organization
Slack channel for real-time help

title: Day 2: Claude Code Hackathon
text:
Location
All hackathon activities will be held in the main conference room at ETH Zurich. Breakout spaces available for team work.

title: Why Claude Code
text:
Time: 09:30-10:00
Format: Presentation and demonstration

title: Why Claude Code
text:
Session Overview
Discover how Claude Code can accelerate your development workflow and enable you to build more ambitious projects during today’s hackathon.

title: Why Claude Code
text:
What is Claude Code?
Claude Code is an AI-powered development assistant that can:

Write, debug, and refactor code
Explain complex codebases
Generate documentation
Suggest improvements
Help with API integrations
Assist with data processing

title: Why Claude Code
section: Why Use Claude Code for openwashdata?
text:
Why Use Claude Code for openwashdata?

1. Rapid Prototyping

Quickly generate boilerplate code
Implement complex algorithms
Create data processing pipelines
Build visualization components



2. Learning Acceleration

Understand unfamiliar codebases
Learn new programming languages
Explore best practices
Get instant explanations



3. Quality Improvement

Catch bugs early
Improve code structure
Ensure consistent style
Add comprehensive testing



4. Documentation

Generate clear documentation
Create usage examples
Write API references
Explain complex logic

title: Why Claude Code
text:
Real-World Examples
During this session, we’ll demonstrate:

Data Pipeline Creation

Processing raw water quality data
Validation and cleaning
Format transformation

Visualization Development

Creating interactive charts
Building dashboards
Responsive design

API Integration

Connecting to openwashdata APIs
Authentication handling
Error management

title: Why Claude Code
text:
Best Practices

Effective Prompting

Be specific about requirements
Provide context and examples
Iterate on responses
Verify generated code



Working with Claude Code

Start with clear problem definition
Break down complex tasks
Review and understand generated code
Test incrementally
Refine based on results



Limitations to Consider

Always review generated code
Test thoroughly
Understand what you’re implementing
Use for assistance, not replacement

title: Why Claude Code
text:
Hackathon Integration
How to leverage Claude Code today:

Planning: Outline project architecture
Implementation: Generate code snippets
Debugging: Identify and fix issues
Documentation: Create project docs
Learning: Understand new concepts

title: Why Claude Code
text:
Resources

Claude Code Documentation
Example prompts for common tasks
Code templates for openwashdata
Best practices guide







Pro Tip



Claude Code works best when you maintain a conversation. Build on previous responses and provide feedback for better results.

title: Day 2 Prerequisites
text:
Complete Before the Conference



Please complete all steps below before Day 2 of the conference to ensure you can fully participate in the hackathon.

title: Day 2 Prerequisites
text:
Overview
Day 2 features a hands-on hackathon using Claude Code. The following are setup steps to ensure you can effectively use Claude Code and participate in the hackathon. The steps are listed for MacOS and Windows users, so please follow the instructions for your operating system. The steps for Windows were not tested, so please reach out if you encounter any issues.

title: Day 2 Prerequisites
text:
Required Setup Steps

1. Get Claude Code Max Plan
Claude Code requires a subscription to the Max plan for full functionality.

Visit Claude.ai
Sign up or log in to your account
Subscribe to the Claude Max plan ($100/month)
Send your invoice to Lars







Tip



You can cancel the subscription after the conference if you don’t wish to continue using it. You will have access to it for 1 month.




2. Verify Terminal Access
You’ll need to use the terminal/command line during the hackathon.

macOSWindows



Press Cmd + Space to open Spotlight
Type “Terminal” and press Enter
You should see a window with a command prompt
Type echo "Terminal works!" and press Enter
If you see “Terminal works!” printed, you’re all set



Recommended: Windows Terminal

Install Windows Terminal from the Microsoft Store
Once installed, press Win key and type “Windows Terminal”
Click to open Windows Terminal
In the terminal, type echo Terminal works! and press Enter
If you see “Terminal works!” printed, you’re all set






3. Install Python
Python is required for many data processing tasks.

macOSWindows



Check if Python is installed:
python3 --version
If not installed, install using Homebrew:
# Install Homebrew first if you don't have it
/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"

# Then install Python
brew install python
Verify installation:
python3 --version
pip3 --version




Download Python from python.org
Run the installer
Important: Check “Add Python to PATH” during installation
Open a new command prompt and verify:
python --version
pip --version






4. GitHub Account Setup
Ensure you can access your GitHub account:

Go to github.com
Log in to your account
Verify you can access your profile and repositories
Recommended: Set up two-factor authentication



5. Create Local Working Directory
Create a dedicated folder for storing code repositories locally (not in cloud-synced folders). The recommended location is in your Documents folder, named gitrepos. Use your preferred way of creating directories (Finder, File Explorer, or terminal/command line).
Below are the terminal commands for both macOS and Windows users.

macOSWindows


# Create the directory in Documents
mkdir -p ~/Documents/gitrepos

# Navigate to it
cd ~/Documents/gitrepos

# Verify it exists
pwd
You should see: /Users/yourusername/Documents/gitrepos


# Create the directory in Documents
mkdir %USERPROFILE%\Documents\gitrepos

# Navigate to it
cd %USERPROFILE%\Documents\gitrepos

# Verify it exists
cd
You should see: C:\Users\yourusername\Documents\gitrepos









Important: Avoid Cloud-Synced Folders



Do not create your gitrepos folder inside: - OneDrive - Google Drive - Dropbox - iCloud Drive
These services can interfere with Git operations.




6. Accept GitHub Organization Invitation
Before the conference, you’ll receive an invitation to join the openwashdata-conf GitHub organization.

Check your email for the invitation
Click the invitation link
Accept the invitation to join the organization
Verify access at: github.com/openwashdata-conf







Note



If you haven’t received an invitation by July 10, please contact the organizing team.

title: Day 2 Prerequisites
text:
Verification Checklist
Before Day 2, ensure you can check all these boxes:

Claude Code Max plan active
Terminal/command line accessible
Python installed and working
GitHub account accessible
Local gitrepos folder created
Member of openwashdata-conf organization

title: Day 2 Prerequisites
text:
Need Help?
If you encounter any issues during setup:

Check our troubleshooting guide below
Ask in the conference Element channel
Email Lars directly (you have his email address)

title: Day 2 Prerequisites
text:
Troubleshooting

Common Issues
Claude Code won’t install

Ensure you have admin rights on your computer
Temporarily disable antivirus during installation
Try downloading again with a different browser

Python command not found

Restart your terminal after installation
Ensure Python was added to PATH during installation
Try python3 instead of python on macOS/Linux

Can’t create gitrepos folder

Ensure you have write permissions
Try creating in your user home directory
Avoid special characters in the path

GitHub invitation not received

Check spam/junk folders
Verify your email address with organizers
Request a resend if needed

title: openwashdata Conference 2025
text: Welcome to the openwashdata Conference 2025! Join us for three days of collaboration, learning, and community building.

title: Lean Coffee Session
text:
Time: TBD (Afternoon session)
Format: Lean Coffee methodology

title: Lean Coffee Session
text:
What is Lean Coffee?
Lean Coffee is a structured, but agenda-less meeting format. Participants gather, build an agenda, and begin conversing. Conversations are directed and productive because the agenda for the meeting was democratically generated.

title: Lean Coffee Session
text:
How It Works

1. Setup (5 minutes)
Three columns are created:

To Discuss: Topics waiting to be discussed
Discussing: Current topic
Discussed: Completed topics



2. Generate Topics (5-10 minutes)
Everyone writes topics on sticky notes:

One topic per note
Brief, clear descriptions
Questions, concerns, or ideas
Related to openwashdata



3. Vote on Topics (5 minutes)
Democratic prioritization:

Each person gets 2-3 votes
Vote for topics of interest
Can use multiple votes on one topic
Topics ranked by vote count



4. Discuss Topics (45-60 minutes)
Structured conversations:

Start with highest-voted topic
Set timer for 5 minutes
When timer ends, vote to continue or move on
If continuing, add 3 more minutes
Move completed topics to “Discussed”



5. Close and Actions (5 minutes)
Wrap up the session:

Summarize key insights
Identify action items
Assign owners to actions
Share notes with group

title: Lean Coffee Session
text:
Why Lean Coffee?

Benefits

Democratic: Everyone has equal voice
Efficient: Time-boxed discussions
Flexible: Addresses current concerns
Engaging: Active participation



Perfect For

Surfacing community concerns
Generating new ideas
Problem-solving
Knowledge sharing

title: Lean Coffee Session
text:
Potential Topics
Past Lean Coffee sessions have covered:

Technical challenges in data collection
Community engagement strategies
Funding and sustainability
Tool development priorities
Partnership opportunities
Training and capacity building

title: Lean Coffee Session
text:
Tips for Success

Keep topics focused and specific
Be concise in discussions
Listen actively to others
Build on others’ ideas
Focus on actionable outcomes







Come Prepared



Think about topics you’d like to discuss with the community. The best Lean Coffee sessions address real, current challenges and opportunities.

title: Hackathon Ideation
text:
Time: TBD (Afternoon session)
Format: Collaborative brainstorming

title: Hackathon Ideation
text:
Session Overview
Prepare for Day 2’s hackathon by generating and refining project ideas. This session will help form teams and define project scopes that can be realistically achieved during the hackathon.

title: Hackathon Ideation
text:
Ideation Process
We’ll be using a collaborative Google Doc to capture and organize ideas throughout this session.

1. Problem Identification (20 min)
Identify key challenges in the water and sanitation data space:

Data collection gaps
Analysis tool needs
Visualization requirements
Data quality issues
Accessibility challenges



2. Solution Brainstorming (30 min)
Generate potential solutions using:

Individual idea generation
Small group discussions
Rapid prototyping sketches
Technology stack considerations



3. Project Pitches (30 min)
Quick presentations of project ideas:

2-minute pitches per idea
Problem statement
Proposed solution
Required skills/team members
Expected outcomes



4. Team Formation (20 min)
Self-organize into hackathon teams:

Match skills to project needs
Balance team sizes (3-5 people)
Designate team leads
Exchange contact information

title: Hackathon Ideation
text:
Project Criteria
Good hackathon projects should be:

Achievable: Can be completed in one day
Relevant: Addresses real openwashdata needs
Collaborative: Requires diverse skills
Demonstrable: Has clear outputs to showcase

title: Hackathon Ideation
text:
Example Project Types

Data processing pipelines
Visualization dashboards
API development
Documentation improvements
Data quality tools
Mobile data collection apps

title: Hackathon Ideation
text:
Resources for Teams

Claude Code for development assistance
openwashdata datasets for testing
GitHub repositories for collaboration
Technical mentors available

title: Hackathon Ideation
text:
Next Steps
After this session:

Teams finalize project scopes
Set up GitHub repositories
Prepare development environments
Review Day 2 prerequisites







Pro Tip



Don’t aim for perfection! Focus on creating a working prototype that demonstrates your idea.

title: Governance
text:
Why Governance Matters


Without Good Governance:

Low productivity
Opaque decision-making
Unclear leadership
Frustration and conflicts
Difficulty scaling


With Good Governance:

Clear processes
Transparent decisions
Defined roles
Sustainable growth
Community trust

title: Governance
text:
Governance Evolution Stages


Early Stage (1-3 people)

“Just do it” approach
Minimal formal process
Direct communication

Growing Stage (4-8 people)

Need for coordination
Emerging documentation
Basic collaboration tools

Mature Stage (9+ people)

Formal decision-making
Comprehensive documentation
Structured contribution process

title: Governance
text:
Where is openwashdata Today?


Current State: - Growing community - Multiple contributors - Various projects - Informal coordination

Next Steps: - Define governance model - Document processes - Clarify roles - Establish standards




Reflection Exercise (5 min)
Think about: Where do you see openwashdata in this evolution?

title: Governance
text:
Common Governance Models


Benevolent Dictator

Single leader makes final decisions
Common in early projects

Elected Representatives

Community elects leaders
Fixed terms and rotation

Consensus-Based

All members have equal say
Decisions by agreement

Hybrid Models

Combine elements
Adapt to community needs

title: Governance
text:
Decision-Making: Martha’s Rules
A lightweight framework for inclusive decision-making:

Proposal Submission

Anyone can propose
Written in advance
Clear and specific

Preliminary Vote

Thumbs up: Agree
Thumbs sideways: Discuss more
Thumbs down: Serious concerns

Discussion & Revision

Address concerns
Modify proposal

Final Vote

Clear majority needed
Document decision

title: Governance
text:
Key Governance Components

1. Roles & Responsibilities


Maintainers: Technical decisions, code review
Contributors: Submit data, code, documentation
Stewards: Community management, outreach
Users: Feedback, bug reports



Question: What roles do we need in openwashdata?

title: Governance
text:
Key Governance Components

2. Communication Channels


Internal: - Slack/Discord - Regular meetings - Email lists - GitHub discussions

External: - Website - Blog posts - Social media - Conference talks

title: Governance
text:
Key Governance Components

3. Documentation
Essential documents for any open community:


README: Project overview
CONTRIBUTING: How to participate
CODE_OF_CONDUCT: Community standards
LICENSE: Legal framework
GOVERNANCE: Decision processes

title: Governance
text:
Community Standards

Code of Conduct Essentials


Clear expectations for behavior
Specific examples of unacceptable conduct
Enforcement mechanisms that are fair
Reporting process that is safe
Consequences that are proportionate



Remember: A code without enforcement is just decoration

title: Governance
text:
Meeting Management Best Practices


Before: - Is meeting necessary? - Clear agenda - Shared in advance - Assigned moderator

During: - Start on time - Follow agenda - Encourage participation - Take minutes



After: Share minutes, action items, deadlines

title: Governance
text:
Interactive Exercise: Governance Assessment
15 minutes - Small Groups
Discuss and answer:

Who are our users? How do they find us?
How do we make decisions currently?
What gets in the way of contributions?
How do we handle conflicts?
How do we welcome newcomers?
What could we automate?


Share: Each group presents one key insight

title: Governance
text:
Proposed Governance Framework
Based on best practices and community needs:


Steering Committee (3-5 members, rotating)
Working Groups (data quality, tools, outreach)
Decision Process (Martha’s Rules for major decisions)
Documentation (all five essential documents)
Regular Reviews (quarterly governance check-ins)

title: Governance
text:
Action Planning

Immediate Actions (Next 30 days)


Draft CODE_OF_CONDUCT
Create CONTRIBUTING guide
Define initial roles
Set up communication channels




Medium-term (3-6 months)


Implement decision process
Form working groups
Regular community calls
Document all processes

title: Governance
text:
Small Group Discussion (20 min)
Break into groups of 3-4 to discuss:

Which governance model fits openwashdata best?
What roles do we need to define first?
What decisions need a formal process?
How do we ensure inclusive participation?


Report Back: Each group shares top priority

title: Governance
text:
Synthesis & Next Steps

Key Takeaways


Governance enables growth
Start simple, evolve as needed
Document everything
Be inclusive by design
Review and adapt regularly

title: Governance
text:
Your Commitment
Before we close, consider:


What governance aspect excites you most?
Where could you contribute?
What concerns do you have?
What support do you need?



Share: One commitment or question with the group

title: Governance
text:
Resources

The Turing Way - Guide for Collaboration
Open Source Guides - Leadership & Governance
Apache Software Foundation - How it Works
Research Software Engineering Handbook

title: Governance
text:
Thank You!


Let’s build a sustainable, inclusive governance model together!
Questions? Thoughts? Concerns?

title: Day 1: Community & Governance
text:
Laptop: Required for shared note-taking, especially in the afternoon sessions.
Google Doc access: We will take notes in a shared Google Doc. You will receive an email to test if you can access it. If you did not receive an email, please contact the organizers.
Ideas for Hackathon: Think about potential projects or topics you or somene else could work on during the hackathon on Day 2.

title: Governance
text:
A 10X engineer is one who can bring together ten other engineers and emerge with a shared understanding and rough consensus of the problem being solved and work that needs to be done.
— Lorin Hochstein


In this house we call them “project managers”.
— Greg Wilson

title: Governance
text:
Software is created and run to answer a question
Papers, theses, and other reports are the product
The software is “just” a tool
Shades into projects that produce software for other researchers to use

title: Governance
text:
Degree(s) in some research domain
Little or no formal training in software development
In a team of 1–12 people
Timelines of weeks to months




XKCD Dependency cartoon

title: Governance
text:
Don’t remember much statistics…
…but I’ve built a lot of complicated software…
…and I’ve been lucky enough to hang out with some very smart people

title: Governance
text:
Then


Now


Next




Dropbox


Git repository


Branching workflow




“Just do it”


Slack / mailing list


Martha’s Rules




Interactive analysis


A big pile of scripts


Build tools / CI




Word / Google Docs


Notebooks / LaTeX


Site builder




“It doesn’t crash”


“Are there any NAs?”


Assertions / unit tests




“Um, hi?”


README + LICENSE


CONTRIBUTING + CoC

title: Governance
text:
Original workshop: Daniel Standage and Greg Wilson
Producing Open Source Software: Karl Fogel
Research Software Engineering with Python: Damien Irving, Kate Hertweck, Luke Johnston, Joel Ostblom, Charlotte Wickham, and Greg Wilson
And everyone cited in the bibliography




Cover of ‘Research Software Engineering with Python’

title: Governance
text:
Who uses your software?
How do they find it?
Who decides what will happen next?
How is that communicated?
Who can make what kinds of changes?
What happens automatically?
How are newcomers brought on board?

title: Governance
section: What problems are we trying to solve?
text:
What problems are we trying to solve?

Low productivity

“Oh no: not another meeting…”

Opaque decision making

“Did we decide that?”
“It’s not what you know, it’s who you know.”

title: Governance
text:
The good news

You don’t have to invent this yourself
https://www.askamanager.org/




Ask a Manager logo

title: Governance
text:
Governance models

https://communityrule.info/ describes lots of options
Benevolent dictator (often the project founder)

Common in young projects
Brittle (founder can move on)
Usually leads to emergence of unofficial (i.e., unaccountable) leaders

Elected representation

Explicit rules for suffrage

Consensus-based

If most people agree on most things most of the time

title: Governance
text: sidebar

title: Governance
text:
“Hero” programmers

Brooks advocated a chief programmer model in the 1970s [@Brooks1995]

Disparaged since then

But 80% of projects on GitHub are hero projects [@Majumder2019]

5% or less of people responsible for 95% or more of interactions
“Heroes” commit far fewer bugs than other contributors

Despite terminology, not a bad model for research projects

[@Petre2014] found that people without domain knowledge couldn’t review scientific code effectively

title: Governance
text:
Martha’s Rules

Anyone can put forward a proposal by filing it at least 24 hours before a scheduled meeting

One-line summary
Background information
Concrete proposal
Pros and cons
Alternatives

At most two pages

Preferably shorter

title: Governance
text:
Establishing a quorum

A quorum is established if half or more of voting members are present
Which means there must be:

A rule about how to become a member
A rule about when and how someone stops being a member

The meeting may not discuss or vote on a proposal unless its sponsor (or their delegate) is present.

title: Governance
text:
Presenting a proposal

The sponsor has 5 minutes to present the proposal
Members cast a sense vote: support, neutral, or oppose

If everyone supports or is neutral, go immediately to a binary vote with no further discussion
If a majority is opposed or neutral, send proposal back to sponsor for further work

If a minority of members oppose, set a timer for 10 minutes of moderated discussion
Then call a final binary vote in which everyone must support or oppose (no neutral votes allowed)
If a majority support, the proposal is accepted

Otherwise, it is returned to the sponsor for further work

title: Governance
text:
Roles and responsibilities




Person


Roles




Role


Task




ghopper


admin


admin


merge PRs




kjohnson


admin, commit


×


admin


assign issues




aturing


commit




commit


publish posts




bwk


commit


commit


file issues





Gives you a list of what actually needs to be done

It’s always longer than you first expect

Tells everyone who to go to for what

Particularly when their first choice is on holiday

Helps with succession planning

“We don’t have anyone who does that any more…”

title: Governance
text:
Code of Conduct

Diverse communities need explicit norms

“I didn’t realize someone would find that offensive”
Which is sometimes used dishonestly…

Adopt a Code of Conduct (e.g., Python’s)

Its mere existence is a strong signal about the kind of community you are

Don’t write one yourself

You won’t think of all the edge cases
Using someone else’s makes misunderstandings less likely

Use the Contributor Covenant

title: Governance
text:
Code of Conduct

A Code of Conduct is only useful if it is enforced

And if there is a clear reporting mechanism that community members trust

Be explicit about enforcement mechanisms and consequences
Designate an independent third party to handle complaints

Trade off with another project lead
Do the background reading [@Aurora2019]

title: Governance
text:
Meetings

On par with interruptions for “things people wish they could have less of”
Unlike interruptions, can be done well
As with governance, having rules is the first and biggest step toward efficiency

title: Governance
section: 1. Does there actually need to be a meeting?
text:
1. Does there actually need to be a meeting?

To inform? Only if you are expecting questions
To consult? Only if people get a vote

Otherwise it’s just informing with pretense

To discuss and make decisions? Yes

But only in small groups
Or with well-defined procedural rules

To brainstorm or collaborate?

That’s a very different kind of meeting

title: Governance
text:
2. Create an agenda

If you don’t care enough to make a list, you don’t need a meeting
Include timings
Prioritize
Plan to end early

“The most fundamental unit of time is the bladder”

title: Governance
section: 3. Have clear rules for making decisions
text:
3. Have clear rules for making decisions

“The Tyranny of Structurelessness” [@Freeman1972]
If you need Robert’s Rules, you need training

title: Governance
text:
4. Put someone in charge

The moderator should not do most of the talking

Any more than the conductor plays most of the notes

Call on specific people in order
Allow them one point at a time
Keep a backlog

title: Governance
text:
5. Require politeness

All the other rules are special cases of this…
No technology during in-person meeting

Except for assistive technology or family need
“Please put your devices in politeness mode”

No interruptions

Except by moderator

No rambling
You do have a Code of Conduct, right?

title: Governance
text:
6. Record minutes

So people who weren’t there know what happened
So people who were there agree what happened
So people can be held accountable at later meetings

title: Governance
Governance
text:
8. Be an active participant

Decline invitations

If you agree to abide by what the meeting decides

Read the agenda and material before the meeting
Take your own notes
Use participants’ names
Pause before speaking
Put down your hand

title: Governance
text:
9. Life online

No mixed-mode meetings

All in person or all online

Do not record the meeting without willing consent
Review meeting protocol at the start if necessary
Take minutes in a shared document
Raise hands digitally

/hand in the chat is good
/hand another budget item is better

title: Governance
text:
10. Seek truth, not victory

No social dominance displays

“Well actually…”

Don’t raise points you don’t actually believe in

The devil doesn’t need more advocates

Don’t make excuses for your questions or opinions

“This is probably stupid, but…”

title: Governance
text: sidebar

title: Governance
text:
Recommended reading

[@Brookfield2016] has a lot of good ideas for managing discussion

title: Governance
text: exercise

title: Governance
text:
Decision making

What decisions has your project made recently?
Who made them?
Where are they recorded?

title: Governance
text: exercise

title: Governance
section: What roles and responsibilities do you have?
text:
What roles and responsibilities do you have?

List a dozen things people do to keep your project going in Column A.
List people who contribute to the project in Column B.
Draw lines to connect them. What roles can you identify?

title: Governance
text: exercise

title: Governance
text:
Who decides?

Who gets a vote in your group?
How are new people added to that pool?
When and how do people lose their votes?
Where and how do other people find out what has been decided and how it affects them?
Where and how can non-voters raise issues?

text: past and future

With Good Governance:

text:

Next Steps: - Define governance model - Document processes - Clarify roles - Establish standards




Reflection Exercise (5 min)

title: Governance
text:
Common Governance Models


Benevolent Dictator

Single leader makes final decisions
Common in early projects

Elected Representatives

Community elects leaders
Fixed terms and rotation

Consensus-Based

All members have equal say
Decisions by agreement

Hybrid Models

Combine elements
Adapt to community needs

title: Governance
text:
Decision-Making: Martha’s Rules
A lightweight framework for inclusive decision-making:

Proposal Submission

Anyone can propose
Written in advance
Clear and specific

Preliminary Vote

Thumbs up: Agree
Thumbs sideways: Discuss more
Thumbs down: Serious concerns

Discussion & Revision

Address concerns
Modify proposal

Final Vote

Clear majority needed
Document decision

title: Governance
text:
Key Governance Components

1. Roles & Responsibilities


Maintainers: Technical decisions, code review
Contributors: Submit data, code, documentation
Stewards: Community management, outreach
Users: Feedback, bug reports



Question: What roles do we need in openwashdata?

title: Governance
text:
Key Governance Components

2. Communication Channels


Internal: - Slack/Discord - Regular meetings - Email lists - GitHub discussions

External: - Website - Blog posts - Social media - Conference talks

title: Governance
text:
Key Governance Components

3. Documentation
Essential documents for any open community:


README: Project overview
CONTRIBUTING: How to participate
CODE_OF_CONDUCT: Community standards
LICENSE: Legal framework
GOVERNANCE: Decision processes

title: Governance
text:
Community Standards

Code of Conduct Essentials


Clear expectations for behavior
Specific examples of unacceptable conduct
Enforcement mechanisms that are fair
Reporting process that is safe
Consequences that are proportionate



Remember: A code without enforcement is just decoration

title: Governance
text:
Meeting Management Best Practices


Before: - Is meeting necessary? - Clear agenda - Shared in advance - Assigned moderator

During: - Start on time - Follow agenda - Encourage participation - Take minutes



After: Share minutes, action items, deadlines

title: Governance
text:
Interactive Exercise: Governance Assessment
15 minutes - Small Groups
Discuss and answer:

Who are our users? How do they find us?
How do we make decisions currently?
What gets in the way of contributions?
How do we handle conflicts?
How do we welcome newcomers?
What could we automate?


Share: Each group presents one key insight

title: Governance
text:
Proposed Governance Framework
Based on best practices and community needs:


Steering Committee (3-5 members, rotating)
Working Groups (data quality, tools, outreach)
Decision Process (Martha’s Rules for major decisions)
Documentation (all five essential documents)
Regular Reviews (quarterly governance check-ins)

title: Governance
text:
Action Planning

Immediate Actions (Next 30 days)


Draft CODE_OF_CONDUCT
Create CONTRIBUTING guide
Define initial roles
Set up communication channels




Medium-term (3-6 months)


Implement decision process
Form working groups
Regular community calls
Document all processes

title: Governance
text:
Small Group Discussion (20 min)
Break into groups of 3-4 to discuss:

Which governance model fits openwashdata best?
What roles do we need to define first?
What decisions need a formal process?
How do we ensure inclusive participation?


Report Back: Each group shares top priority

title: Governance
text:
Synthesis & Next Steps

Key Takeaways


Governance enables growth
Start simple, evolve as needed
Document everything
Be inclusive by design
Review and adapt regularly

title: Governance
text:
Your Commitment
Before we close, consider:


What governance aspect excites you most?
Where could you contribute?
What concerns do you have?
What support do you need?



Share: One commitment or question with the group

title: Governance
text:
Resources

The Turing Way - Guide for Collaboration
Open Source Guides - Leadership & Governance
Apache Software Foundation - How it Works
Research Software Engineering Handbook

title: Governance
text:
Thank You!


Let’s build a sustainable, inclusive governance model together!
Questions? Thoughts? Concerns?

title: Introduction
text:
A 10X engineer is one who can bring together ten other engineers and emerge with a shared understanding and rough consensus of the problem being solved and work that needs to be done.
— Lorin Hochstein


In this house we call them “project managers”.
— Greg Wilson

title: Introduction
text:
A 10X engineer is one who can bring together ten other engineers and emerge with a shared understanding and rough consensus of the problem being solved and work that needs to be done.
— Lorin Hochstein


In this house we call them “project managers”.
— Greg Wilson

title: Introduction
text:
Research software

Software is created and run to answer a question
Papers, theses, and other reports are the product
The software is “just” a tool
Shades into projects that produce software for other researchers to use

title: Introduction
text:
You

Degree(s) in some research domain
Little or no formal training in software development
In a team of 1–12 people
Timelines of weeks to months




XKCD Dependency cartoon

title: Introduction
text:
Me

Don’t remember much statistics…
…but I’ve built a lot of complicated software…
…and I’ve been lucky enough to hang out with some very smart people

title: Introduction
section: Where we’ve been, where we’re going
text:
Where we’ve been, where we’re going



Then


Now


Next




Dropbox


Git repository


Branching workflow




“Just do it”


Slack / mailing list


Martha’s Rules




Interactive analysis


A big pile of scripts


Build tools / CI




Word / Google Docs


Notebooks / LaTeX


Site builder




“It doesn’t crash”


“Are there any NAs?”


Assertions / unit tests




“Um, hi?”


README + LICENSE


CONTRIBUTING + CoC

title: Introduction
text:
Acknowledgments

Original workshop: Daniel Standage and Greg Wilson
Producing Open Source Software: Karl Fogel
Research Software Engineering with Python: Damien Irving, Kate Hertweck, Luke Johnston, Joel Ostblom, Charlotte Wickham, and Greg Wilson
And everyone cited in the bibliography




Cover of ‘Research Software Engineering with Python’

title: Introduction
section: How is your project currently run?
text:
How is your project currently run?

Who uses your software?
How do they find it?
Who decides what will happen next?
How is that communicated?
Who can make what kinds of changes?
What happens automatically?
How are newcomers brought on board?
